stream_context.summary: Kaze juggles playtesting polish for Course 2, engine/performance work (ROM space cleanup and faster decompression to reduce load times), and some light asset/animation work (Goomba King fishing). The stream ends with a new crash concern when opening the Cloud Cap stage, plus a concrete to‑do list for post-Bowser world-state changes (destroyed Bowser mech, entrances, Dory chain, minecart).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces meaningful technical progress (recovering ROM space, planned decompression upgrade to cut loading times), signals Course 2 nearing final polish after beta tests, and surfaces a new stability issue (Cloud Cap stage crash) alongside an explicit roadmap for post-Bowser world-state content.

findings.summary: Kaze reclaimed almost half a megabyte of ROM space by deleting unused base Mario 64 assets still present in the ROM, calling it a major win for the project’s remaining content budget.

EggLab pointed Kaze to a decompression algorithm about twice as fast as the current standard; Kaze hopes it will cut a roughly 3-second load time down to ~1.5 seconds, which he considers much more acceptable.
findings.quote: The standard one right now… takes… three seconds of load time, which I think is a little unacceptable.

findings.summary: Kaze observes emulator-vs-hardware differences: Project64 appears "fucked up" relative to his Unreal/N64 test setup, and he suspects some of his graphics-render optimizations may have inadvertently slowed loading.
Course 2 is described as “almost perfect” after extensive beta testing; Kaze is down to one remaining beta-test video to review before considering it essentially done.
findings.quote: I think Course 2 is almost perfect now.

findings.summary: Course 2 underwater section received usability/clarity changes based on feedback: thicker wooden plank, wall coin icons to guide coin hunts, more ground platforms for faster exits, and other small geometry tweaks to reduce annoyance.
Kaze confirms there is some assembly (ASM) in the project, though most work discussed is in higher-level code/tools.

Kaze says once the hack is done he wants to build a full standalone game with his custom engine, and for future “romhack-like” projects (e.g., Zelda) he’d rather recreate the game in his engine than fight the original engine’s constraints.
findings.quote: If I was making a Zelda romhack, I would just make a Zelda game in my engine. It would genuinely be easier than dealing with the actual Zelda engine.

findings.summary: Kaze frames his workload as three simultaneous jobs: his Gears for Breakfast role, YouTube, and developing Return to Yoshi’s Island (QAI). This contextualizes time pressure and why progress is split between polish, engine work, and content.
findings.quote: I fucking have three jobs. The first job is programming at Gears for Breakfast, the second job is making YouTube videos, and the third job is making our QAI.

findings.summary: He prototypes a small prop/animation idea: Goomba King fishing with a rod, positioning it as a comedic “retired king” moment and debating whether fishing location (deck vs elsewhere) makes sense.

A new stability issue appears: the Cloud Cap stage seemingly crashes upon being opened, prompting concern about possible file corruption; Kaze notes he has Git backups but wants to understand the root cause.
findings.quote: Did it fucking crash when I opened the Cloud Cap…? That’s concerning.

findings.summary: Kaze writes a concrete part-two to-do list for the overworld/post-Bowser progression state: add/finish level entrances (incl. Booetrous), make the Bowser mech outside “Bowser’s Burst” destroyed/smoking after beating the first Bowser level, start minecart work, and add a chained Dory in the lake with Yoshi dialogue explaining it.
Kaze mentions F3 is approaching with ~74 submissions; he explains why he doesn’t submit his own games to F3 because posting a trailer on his own channel would get more views without context.

biobak.summary: Biobak appears in chat; Kaze reacts to Biobak’s computer situation and talks about wanting to pay him enough to upgrade hardware, implying an intention to formalize compensation.
Kaze realizes it may be Biobak’s birthday and wishes him happy birthday on stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina returns near the end of stream, which triggers Kaze to wrap up and leave for a baby’s birthday party.

findings.summary: EggLab alerts Kaze to a decompression algorithm that is reportedly ~2x faster than the project’s current approach, potentially halving load times.
A viewer explains VS Codium as a FOSS VS Code fork without Microsoft telemetry; Kaze accepts the summary and treats it as essentially the same editor choice-wise.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If I was making a Zelda romhack, I would just make a Zelda game in my engine. It would genuinely be easier than dealing with the actual Zelda engine.
memorable_quotes.context: A revealing statement of long-term intent: his custom engine is not just for this hack, but a future platform to avoid legacy-engine constraints.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I fucking have three jobs. The first job is programming at Gears for Breakfast, the second job is making YouTube videos, and the third job is making our QAI.
memorable_quotes.context: Captures the pressure/capacity constraints shaping the project’s pace and why he context-switches between polish, engine work, and content.

key_stories.title: Recovering ROM budget and targeting shorter load times
key_stories.summary: Kaze finds significant ROM headroom by removing unused base-game assets and immediately connects that win to player experience by chasing faster load times. This moment highlights the practical constraints of building something new on N64-era limits and how engineering decisions shape feel/polish.
key_stories.challenge: The project needs more space and better loading performance; current load times are about three seconds, which Kaze finds unacceptable.
key_stories.process: He deletes unused vanilla Mario 64 assets (freeing ~0.5 MB). He then plans to swap in EggLab’s faster decompression algorithm and compares behavior across environments (Project64 vs hardware/other setup), suspecting some graphics optimizations may have slowed loads.
key_stories.outcome: ROM space is already reclaimed; decompression change is planned as the next lever to roughly halve load times, pending integration/testing.
key_stories.key_quote: So I found almost half a megabyte of ROM space today… by deleting all the unused Mario 64 assets.

key_stories.title: Course 2 beta-test driven polish pass
key_stories.summary: Kaze summarizes a late-stage iteration loop: repeated beta tests lead to quality-of-life revisions rather than major redesign. It’s a snapshot of how the team translates friction reports (annoying hazards, unclear coin routes, slow exits) into concrete geometry/signposting changes.
key_stories.challenge: Course 2 had multiple “annoying” friction points—especially in an underwater section—and needed clearer guidance and smoother traversal.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviews beta feedback and implements targeted tweaks: making key geometry thicker, adding coin icons as navigational hints, adding platforms to exit water faster, and adjusting placements/alignments on the fly.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze says Course 2 is nearly final, with only one remaining beta test video to review before he considers it effectively finished.
key_stories.key_quote: I think Course 2 is almost perfect now.

key_stories.title: Cloud Cap stage crash reveals fragility during engine reworks
key_stories.summary: While moving into a second work block, Kaze hits an unexpected crash when opening the Cloud Cap stage. It underscores the risk of ongoing engine refactors: content tooling can become unstable even as gameplay content nears completion.
key_stories.challenge: Opening the Cloud Cap stage appears to crash, raising fear of corruption or a broken pipeline.
key_stories.process: Kaze acknowledges concern but notes he uses Git backups; he decides it’s more important to diagnose why it broke than to simply restore a backup and move on.
key_stories.outcome: Unresolved by stream end; he explicitly plans to investigate before the next stream.
key_stories.key_quote: I’d rather find out why it’s not working.

open_questions.context: Kaze wants to integrate EggLab’s decompression algorithm (claimed ~2x faster) to cut load times from ~3 seconds to ~1.5 seconds; he also suspects prior render optimizations may have hurt loading.
questions: What exactly is the current decompression path in Return to Yoshi’s Island (where does time go: IO, decompression, DMA, cache, init)?
What did EggLab’s algorithm change under the hood, and what tradeoffs did it introduce (ROM size, RAM usage, complexity, compatibility with tools/emulators)?
How will you validate load-time improvements across real hardware vs Project64, given you already see environment-specific behavior?
You mentioned graphics optimizations might have slowed loading—what optimization was that, and why would it affect load time?

open_questions.topic: ROM space recovery strategy and future budgeting
open_questions.context: Kaze freed ~0.5 MB by deleting unused vanilla assets left in the ROM, framing it as a major gain.
questions: Which categories of vanilla assets were still present (textures, geo layouts, animations, audio), and how did you determine they were truly unused in your build?
Did removing them require any refactors to the build system or asset pipeline to prevent reintroducing them later?
How do you decide what that reclaimed half-megabyte gets spent on—new levels, cutscenes, audio, or engine features?

open_questions.topic: Cloud Cap stage crash root cause
open_questions.context: The project crashes when Kaze opens the Cloud Cap stage; he has Git backups but wants to understand the failure.
questions: What changed most recently before the Cloud Cap crash (engine refactor, asset format changes, editor/tooling updates)?
Is this crash reproducible on a fresh checkout/build, and does it happen on hardware or only in a specific tool/emulator path?
What’s your usual triage process for these failures—do you bisect with Git, add asserts/logging, or validate asset integrity first?

open_questions.topic: Post-Bowser world-state plan (destroyed mech, Dory chain, entrances)
open_questions.context: Kaze lists tasks to make the world react to beating the first Bowser: a destroyed/smoking mech outside Bowser’s Burst, a chained Dory in the lake with Yoshi dialogue, plus level entrances and minecart work.
questions: What’s the intended narrative/atmospheric purpose of leaving the destroyed Bowser mech in the world—does it signal progress, stakes, or guide the player?
How are you implementing persistent world changes on N64—flags, save bits, or custom state tracking—and what’s the risk of bugs/regressions?
For the Dory chain + Yoshi hint: what problem is it solving in player navigation, and how did you decide the hint should be explicit vs discoverable?
Where does the minecart fit in the game’s pacing—new traversal mechanic, setpiece level, or overworld transport?
